questions.stem: A researcher presents participants with a 20-item word list, followed by 30 seconds of backward counting, and then asks for free recall. Compared to a condition without the distractor task, which finding is most likely?

options.text: Both the primacy and recency effects are eliminated
The primacy effect is eliminated, but the recency effect is preserved
The recency effect is eliminated, but the primacy effect is preserved
Neither the primacy nor the recency effect is affected

questions.explanation: A distractor task between list presentation and recall selectively eliminates the recency effect because the most recent items are displaced from short-term memory. The primacy effect is preserved because early items have already been transferred to long-term memory through rehearsal. This classic finding supports the Atkinson-Shiffrin dual-store model's distinction between STM and LTM.

questions.stem: A forensic psychologist is evaluating eyewitness testimony. The witness provides a highly detailed, emotionally vivid account of the crime and reports absolute confidence in her memory. Based on memory research, which conclusion is most scientifically supported?

options.text: The vividness and confidence strongly indicate the memory is accurate
High confidence and vividness do not reliably predict memory accuracy
Emotional vividness guarantees accuracy for central details but not peripheral ones
Confidence is a valid predictor of accuracy only for flashbulb memories

questions.explanation: Research consistently demonstrates that confidence and vividness are poor predictors of memory accuracy. Flashbulb memory research shows that while people maintain high confidence over time, the actual accuracy of their memories declines similarly to ordinary memories. This dissociation between confidence and accuracy is a critical EPPP principle for evaluating eyewitness testimony and recovered memories.

questions.stem: A patient reports knowing the name of her childhood teacher but being unable to retrieve it, despite sensing it is 'on the tip of her tongue' and being able to identify the first letter. This experience is best explained by which concept?

options.text: Retroactive interference
Trace decay
Cue-dependent retrieval failure
Motivated forgetting through repression

questions.explanation: The tip-of-the-tongue (TOT) phenomenon is the classic example of cue-dependent retrieval failure. The memory is stored in long-term memory but cannot be fully accessed because the appropriate retrieval cues are insufficient. The person can access partial information (first letter, syllable count) but cannot produce the complete word. This is distinct from decay (the memory still exists) and interference (the issue is absent cues, not competing memories).

questions.stem: In the Deese-Roediger-McDermott (DRM) paradigm, participants study word lists such as 'bed, rest, awake, tired, dream' and are later tested on recognition. Which finding is most characteristic of this paradigm?

options.text: Participants show poor recognition for the studied words due to interference
Participants frequently and confidently recognize a non-presented critical lure word such as 'sleep'
Participants accurately reject the critical lure word when warned about the paradigm
False recognition only occurs when misleading post-event information is provided

questions.explanation: The DRM paradigm demonstrates spontaneous false memory formation through semantic activation. Participants frequently recall or recognize the critical lure (the non-presented word semantically related to all list items) with high confidence, sometimes claiming to vividly remember its presentation. This occurs without any misleading post-event information -- the false memory arises from spreading activation during encoding. Even warnings about the paradigm do not fully eliminate false recognition of the critical lure.

questions.stem: A bilingual psychologist has been practicing therapy in Spanish for the past five years. When she attempts to recall therapeutic vocabulary in French (her first learned language for therapy), she experiences significant difficulty. This difficulty is best attributed to:

options.text: Retroactive interference
Proactive interference
Encoding failure
Source monitoring error

questions.explanation: Retroactive interference occurs when newly learned information interferes with the recall of previously learned information. Here, the more recently learned Spanish vocabulary (new learning) is disrupting retrieval of the previously learned French vocabulary (old learning). Proactive interference would be the reverse -- if the old French vocabulary made it harder to learn or recall the new Spanish terms.

questions.stem: Select ALL factors that have been empirically shown to increase the susceptibility to the misinformation effect. (Select all that apply.)

options.text: The original memory was weakly encoded
The misleading information was presented by an authoritative source
There was a short delay between the original event and the misleading information
The participant has high working memory capacity
There was a long delay between the original event and the misleading information

questions.explanation: The misinformation effect is more powerful when: (1) the original memory is weak or poorly encoded, (2) the misleading information is presented with authority or perceived credibility, and (3) there is a long delay between the original event and exposure to misinformation (allowing the original trace to weaken). A short delay and high working memory capacity would both tend to reduce susceptibility, not increase it.

questions.stem: A neuropsychologist is assessing memory in an older adult. Which of the following are accurate statements about source monitoring errors? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: They involve correctly remembering information but misattributing its origin
They are particularly common in individuals with frontal lobe dysfunction
They increase with age
They require exposure to misleading post-event information
They are a reliable indicator of intentional deception

questions.explanation: Source monitoring errors involve correct recall of content but incorrect attribution of the source. They are more common in children, older adults, and individuals with frontal lobe dysfunction (the frontal lobes play a critical role in source monitoring processes). They do not require misleading post-event information -- they can occur spontaneously when similar sources are confused. They are not indicators of intentional deception; they are genuine memory errors.

questions.stem: Regarding the American Psychological Association's position on recovered memories of trauma, which of the following statements are accurate? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Both genuine recovered memories and false memories can exist
It is currently impossible to distinguish recovered memories from false memories based on vividness or confidence alone
Hypnosis is recommended as an effective technique for recovering accurate traumatic memories
Suggestive therapeutic techniques can create false memories
All recovered memories should be treated as factually accurate in clinical settings

questions.explanation: The APA acknowledges that both genuine recovered memories and false memories exist, and that it is impossible to distinguish between them based on subjective qualities like vividness, emotional intensity, or confidence. The APA specifically warns against suggestive techniques (hypnosis, guided imagery, dream interpretation for memory recovery) as these can create false memories. Neither blanket acceptance nor blanket rejection of recovered memories is scientifically supported.

questions.stem: Which of the following correctly describe differences between recall and recognition as retrieval processes? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Recall provides fewer retrieval cues than recognition
Recognition is generally more difficult than recall
In recognition, the correct answer itself serves as a retrieval cue
The relearning (savings) method can detect memory traces when both recall and recognition fail
Recall and recognition rely on identical neural substrates

questions.explanation: Recall requires generating information from memory with minimal cues, while recognition involves identifying previously encountered information from alternatives, making recognition generally easier. The correct answer in recognition tasks acts as its own retrieval cue. The relearning (savings) method, developed by Ebbinghaus, is the most sensitive measure of retention -- it can detect residual memory traces even when conscious recall and recognition fail. Recall and recognition involve overlapping but distinct neural processes.

questions.stem: Which of the following are true regarding proactive interference (PI) and aging? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Older adults are more susceptible to proactive interference than younger adults
Increased susceptibility to PI in aging may reflect reduced inhibitory control
Release from PI is a procedure that can assess frontal lobe function
Proactive interference decreases with age because older adults have fewer competing memories
Proactive interference exclusively affects procedural memory systems

questions.explanation: Proactive interference increases with age due to two factors: (1) older adults have accumulated more competing memories over their lifetime, and (2) age-related decline in inhibitory control (mediated by the prefrontal cortex) makes it harder to suppress irrelevant competing information. The release-from-PI paradigm is a sensitive indicator of frontal lobe function. PI primarily affects declarative memory, not exclusively procedural memory.

questions.stem: Match each memory phenomenon with the researcher or paradigm most closely associated with it.

rows.text: Spontaneous false memory for semantic associates

questions.explanation: Ebbinghaus (1885) conducted the first systematic study of forgetting using nonsense syllables, producing the classic forgetting curve. Loftus demonstrated the misinformation effect, showing that leading questions and post-event information can alter memory. The DRM paradigm demonstrates spontaneous false memories for semantically related non-presented words. Anderson and Green (2001) developed the Think/No-Think paradigm to study voluntary memory suppression.

questions.stem: Match each forgetting mechanism with the scenario that best illustrates it.

rows.text: A student who studied French for years now struggles to recall French vocabulary after three years of studying Spanish
A patient cannot recall the name of a familiar actor despite a strong feeling of knowing it
An individual avoids thinking about a humiliating public failure and has difficulty recalling details of the event
A student finds it harder to learn new Italian vocabulary because of previously learned Spanish

questions.explanation: Retroactive interference: new Spanish learning disrupts recall of previously learned French (new disrupts old). Cue-dependent retrieval failure: the TOT phenomenon -- the memory exists but cannot be accessed without the right cue. Motivated forgetting: the individual avoids thinking about the distressing event, consistent with suppression of anxiety-provoking memories. Proactive interference: previously learned Spanish interferes with learning new Italian (old disrupts new).

questions.stem: For each population, select ALL memory distortion effects to which they are particularly vulnerable compared to young adults.
questions.explanation: Children are particularly vulnerable to source monitoring errors (confusing imagined and experienced events) and suggestibility to misinformation (highly susceptible to leading questions). Older adults show increased source monitoring errors and heightened proactive interference susceptibility due to accumulated memories and reduced inhibitory control. Frontal lobe damage impairs both source monitoring (a frontal lobe-dependent process) and resistance to proactive interference. Highly stressed eyewitnesses are vulnerable to misinformation (stress can narrow attention and weaken encoding of peripheral details) and often show a confidence-accuracy dissociation (high confidence with lower accuracy).

questions.stem: For each retrieval concept, select ALL characteristics that accurately describe it.

columns.text: Target serves as its own cue

questions.explanation: Recall requires generating information from memory with minimal environmental cues. Recognition provides the target itself as a retrieval cue, making it generally easier. Relearning (Ebbinghaus's savings method) is the most sensitive measure of retention, detecting memory traces even when recall and recognition fail. The TOT phenomenon involves both minimal cue availability (the person cannot fully access the target) and partial retrieval (first letter, syllable count, related words are accessible).

questions.stem: According to the Ebbinghaus forgetting curve, approximately {{blank1}} of newly learned material is forgotten within the first hour. Forgetting is most rapid {{blank2}} after learning, then the rate of forgetting {{blank3}}. The remaining material that is retained shows relatively {{blank4}} retention over longer periods.

options.text: several days
immediately
one week
one month
accelerates over time
remains constant
decelerates over time
reverses direction
unstable and declining
stable
increasing
zero

questions.explanation: Ebbinghaus's forgetting curve demonstrates that approximately 50% of material is forgotten within the first hour, and about 70% within 24 hours. Forgetting is most rapid immediately after learning, then the rate decelerates significantly. Material that survives the initial steep decline is retained relatively stably over longer periods, reflecting a negatively accelerating function.

questions.stem: In Loftus's classic car accident study, participants who were asked how fast cars were going when they '{{blank1}}' into each other gave the highest speed estimates and were most likely to falsely recall seeing {{blank2}}. This demonstrates the {{blank3}} effect, in which {{blank4}} alters memory for the original event.

options.text: contacted
smashed
hit
bumped
broken glass
a second collision
skid marks
blood
primacy
misinformation
serial position
interference
post-event information
repression
decay
chunking

questions.explanation: In Loftus and Palmer's (1974) study, the verb 'smashed' (versus 'contacted,' 'hit,' 'bumped,' or 'collided') led to the highest speed estimates and was more likely to produce false memories of seeing broken glass that was never present in the video. This is the misinformation effect -- post-event information (the leading question with the word 'smashed') alters memory for the original event.

questions.stem: A 72-year-old patient presents to a neuropsychology clinic reporting increasing difficulty remembering names of acquaintances, frequently confusing details from different conversations, and mixing up whether she read something in a book or heard it from a friend. Her working memory, procedural memory, and general intelligence are intact.

options.text: Age-related decline in frontal lobe inhibitory function
Accumulated competing memory traces from decades of experience
Bilateral hippocampal atrophy causing anterograde amnesia
Motivated forgetting through Freudian repression
Source monitoring errors and proactive interference
Korsakoff's syndrome with confabulation
Encoding failure due to attentional deficits
Release-from-PI paradigm can assess frontal lobe contribution to memory complaints
Source monitoring tasks should be included in the neuropsychological battery
Procedural memory tasks will likely reveal the primary deficit
The pattern indicates early Alzheimer's disease requiring immediate pharmacological intervention

questions.explanation: This patient's presentation -- difficulty with names, confusing conversation details, and misattributing information sources -- is characteristic of age-related source monitoring errors and increased proactive interference. These are driven by frontal lobe decline in inhibitory function and the accumulation of competing memory traces over a lifetime. Appropriate assessment should include release-from-PI paradigms (sensitive to frontal function) and explicit source monitoring tasks. Her intact working memory and procedural memory argue against Alzheimer's disease or Korsakoff's syndrome.

questions.stem: A clinical psychologist is treating a 35-year-old client who reports suddenly 'remembering' childhood sexual abuse during a therapy session involving guided imagery. The client had no prior recollection of abuse and is now highly distressed. The memories are vivid and emotionally intense.

options.text: Use of suggestive therapeutic techniques (guided imagery)
High emotional arousal during the therapy session
The client's intact hippocampal function
The therapist's use of evidence-based CBT techniques
Inability to distinguish genuine recovered memory from therapist-created false memory
The memory is certainly false because repressed memories do not exist
The vividness and emotional intensity confirm the memory is accurate
Avoid further use of suggestive memory recovery techniques
Acknowledge uncertainty -- neither confirm nor deny the memory's accuracy
Use hypnosis to verify the accuracy of the recovered memory
Immediately report the abuse as confirmed based on the client's confidence

questions.explanation: Guided imagery is a suggestive technique that can create false memories, and high emotional arousal during therapy increases suggestibility. The core concern is that it is impossible to distinguish genuine recovered memories from false memories based on vividness, emotional intensity, or confidence alone. The clinician should discontinue suggestive techniques, neither confirm nor deny the memory's accuracy, and avoid hypnosis (another suggestive technique). Both the APA and research evidence support this approach.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that are accurate regarding the serial position effect and its implications for memory theory.
questions.passage: The serial position effect describes the tendency to recall items at the beginning and end of a list better than middle items. [The primacy effect is attributed to items still being active in short-term memory at the time of recall]. [The recency effect is attributed to greater rehearsal time for early items, allowing transfer to long-term memory]. [A distractor task between learning and recall eliminates the recency effect but not the primacy effect]. [This pattern supports the Atkinson-Shiffrin dual-store model's distinction between STM and LTM]. [The primacy effect is eliminated by a distractor task because early items have not yet been consolidated]. [The serial position effect has been consistently replicated across diverse populations and materials].

highlightableSegments.text: The primacy effect is attributed to items still being active in short-term memory at the time of recall
The recency effect is attributed to greater rehearsal time for early items, allowing transfer to long-term memory
A distractor task between learning and recall eliminates the recency effect but not the primacy effect
This pattern supports the Atkinson-Shiffrin dual-store model's distinction between STM and LTM
The primacy effect is eliminated by a distractor task because early items have not yet been consolidated
The serial position effect has been consistently replicated across diverse populations and materials

questions.explanation: Segments h1 and h2 swap the explanations: the primacy effect (not recency) is attributed to rehearsal and LTM transfer, while the recency effect (not primacy) is due to items still being in STM. Segment h3 is correct -- a distractor task eliminates recency but not primacy. Segment h4 is correct -- this dissociation supports the dual-store model. Segment h5 is incorrect -- the primacy effect is NOT eliminated by a distractor task because early items have already been transferred to LTM. Segment h6 is correct -- the serial position effect is a robust, widely replicated phenomenon.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe the current scientific understanding of flashbulb memories.
questions.passage: Flashbulb memories are vivid, detailed memories for the circumstances surrounding emotionally significant events. [Brown and Kulik (1977) proposed a special neural mechanism for their formation]. [Subsequent research has consistently confirmed that flashbulb memories are significantly more accurate than ordinary autobiographical memories]. [Despite their vividness, flashbulb memories are subject to the same distortions and reconstructive errors as ordinary memories]. [People report higher confidence in flashbulb memories compared to ordinary memories, even though accuracy is not correspondingly higher]. [The emotional arousal during encoding guarantees permanent, accurate storage of the event details]. [Flashbulb memories demonstrate that confidence and vividness are unreliable indicators of memory accuracy].

highlightableSegments.text: Brown and Kulik (1977) proposed a special neural mechanism for their formation
Subsequent research has consistently confirmed that flashbulb memories are significantly more accurate than ordinary autobiographical memories
Despite their vividness, flashbulb memories are subject to the same distortions and reconstructive errors as ordinary memories
People report higher confidence in flashbulb memories compared to ordinary memories, even though accuracy is not correspondingly higher
The emotional arousal during encoding guarantees permanent, accurate storage of the event details
Flashbulb memories demonstrate that confidence and vividness are unreliable indicators of memory accuracy

questions.explanation: Brown and Kulik did propose a special mechanism (h1 is correct). However, subsequent research has NOT confirmed superior accuracy -- flashbulb memories decline in accuracy similarly to ordinary memories (h2 is incorrect). They are indeed subject to the same distortions (h3 is correct). The confidence-accuracy dissociation is well documented (h4 is correct). Emotional arousal does not guarantee accurate storage (h5 is incorrect). The broader implication about confidence and vividness being poor accuracy indicators is correct (h6).

questions.stem: Arrange the following stages of the misinformation effect in the correct temporal sequence, from the initial event to the distorted memory report.

items.text: Witness observes the original event and encodes a memory
Time passes, allowing the original memory trace to weaken
Witness is exposed to misleading post-event information (e.g., leading questions)
Misleading information is incorporated into the original memory representation
Witness recalls the event, now blending original and misleading details
Witness reports the distorted memory with high confidence, unaware of the alteration

questions.explanation: The misinformation effect follows a specific temporal sequence: (1) the original event is encoded, (2) time passes and the memory trace weakens, (3) misleading post-event information is introduced, (4) this misinformation becomes integrated with the original memory trace, (5) upon retrieval the witness recalls a blended version, and (6) the witness reports this distorted memory with high confidence, genuinely believing it to be accurate. The delay between encoding and misinformation exposure is critical -- longer delays increase susceptibility.

questions.stem: Arrange the following measures of memory retention from LEAST sensitive (detects the fewest retained memory traces) to MOST sensitive (detects the most retained memory traces).

items.text: Free recall without cues
Serial recall (items in order)
Cued recall with category hints
Recognition from multiple alternatives
Implicit memory priming measures
Relearning (savings method)

questions.explanation: Memory measures vary in sensitivity. Free recall (no cues) is least sensitive because it requires full self-initiated retrieval. Serial recall adds the constraint of order, but both are recall-based and demanding. Cued recall provides hints that increase retrieval success. Recognition provides the target itself as a cue. Implicit priming measures can detect residual memory traces below conscious awareness. The relearning (savings) method is the most sensitive -- Ebbinghaus showed that previously learned material is relearned faster even when all other measures suggest complete forgetting.

questions.stem: A researcher replicates Ebbinghaus's forgetting curve experiment with three groups who study word lists and are tested at different time intervals.
questions.question: Which interpretation of the trend data is most consistent with Ebbinghaus's original findings and interference theory?

options.text: Forgetting accelerates over time, suggesting progressive trace decay
Forgetting is most rapid immediately after learning and then decelerates, consistent with a negatively accelerating function
Forgetting occurs at a constant rate, supporting a linear decay model
The data show complete memory loss by 6 days, indicating that long-term storage did not occur

questions.explanation: The data replicate Ebbinghaus's classic finding: the forgetting rate is highest immediately after learning (42% lost in the first 20 minutes) and then decelerates substantially (only 1% additional loss between day 1 and day 6). This negatively accelerating function means that the material surviving the initial steep decline is retained relatively stably. The 25% retained at 6 days shows that some long-term storage did occur. This pattern is consistent with interference theory -- the most vulnerable traces are disrupted quickly, while more robust traces persist.

questions.stem: A developmental researcher tracks source monitoring accuracy and proactive interference susceptibility across the lifespan in a cross-sectional study.
questions.question: What developmental pattern is supported by these data?

options.text: Both source monitoring accuracy and PI resistance improve linearly throughout the lifespan
Source monitoring and PI resistance show an inverted-U pattern, peaking in young adulthood and declining in both childhood and old age, consistent with frontal lobe maturation and decline
Source monitoring accuracy peaks in childhood and declines steadily, while PI susceptibility remains constant
The data indicate that memory distortions are exclusive to older adults and do not affect children

questions.explanation: Both source monitoring accuracy and resistance to proactive interference follow an inverted-U trajectory across the lifespan, with peak performance in young adulthood. Children show poor source monitoring and high PI susceptibility because their prefrontal cortex is still maturing. Young adults perform best as frontal lobe function peaks. Older adults show declining performance as frontal lobe function deteriorates with aging. This pattern is consistent with the known trajectory of frontal lobe maturation (completed by mid-20s) and age-related frontal decline.

questions.stem: Categorize each memory phenomenon as primarily a problem of encoding, storage, or retrieval.

items.text: Inattentional blindness -- failing to notice and encode a stimulus
Tip-of-the-tongue phenomenon -- knowing you know something but cannot access it
Retroactive interference -- new learning displacing old stored information
Context-dependent forgetting -- performing poorly in a different environment than where learning occurred
Shallow processing -- encoding only surface features of information
Trace decay -- gradual fading of a memory representation over time

questions.explanation: Encoding failures occur when information is never properly processed into memory in the first place -- inattentional blindness (stimulus not noticed) and shallow processing (only surface features encoded) represent encoding-level problems. Storage disruptions involve damage to or degradation of the stored memory trace -- retroactive interference disrupts stored old memories, and trace decay involves gradual fading of the stored trace. Retrieval failures involve memories that exist in storage but cannot be accessed -- the TOT phenomenon and context-dependent forgetting both involve intact stored memories that are temporarily inaccessible.

questions.stem: Categorize each research finding as supporting interference theory, decay theory, or constructive/reconstructive memory theory.

items.text: DRM paradigm: participants falsely recall semantically related non-presented words
Learning a second language makes it harder to recall vocabulary from the first language
Misinformation effect: post-event leading questions alter memory for the original event
Sensory memory traces fade within seconds without rehearsal or additional processing
Previously studied material impairs the learning of new, similar material
Memory for recently unused skills degrades over prolonged periods of disuse without new competing learning

questions.explanation: Interference theory explains forgetting through competition between memories: retroactive interference (second language disrupts first) and proactive interference (old material impairs new learning). Decay theory proposes that memory traces weaken with time without rehearsal, which best explains rapid fading in sensory memory and skill degradation from prolonged disuse without competing learning. Constructive memory theory explains how memories are actively built and distorted: the DRM paradigm shows semantic construction creates false memories, and the misinformation effect shows how post-event information reconstructs the original memory.
